item.title: REVIEW: Hotel Transylvania 3
item.description:
I think I watched the first one when it came out and now I skipped to the 3rd one on a whim for no reason.

There is something so strange about this franchise. The strangeness is something that's expressed in the visuals and the writing in equal measure: it oscillates so rapidly between what it wants to be.

In one second, it's trying to be a Pixar/Dreamworks-esque movie with emotion and weight and willing to live in the pauses. Then, after doing that for half a second, it oscillates to being the cartooniest cartoon to ever bounce across the screen.

Visually, that means poses where the characters look grounded, weighted, and with close to "naturalistic" postures and facial expressions............then rapidly flipped to cartooning meant to match flat 2D styles you'd see in Flintstones, Dexter's Laboratory, Powerpuff Girls, Ren & Stimpy, etc.

In terms of writing, it means brief moments where characters are trying to connect with each other or stop and think........then rapidly flipped to rapid gag-after-gag-after-gag where characters are unshackled by having to act "in-character" or "like real people."

I'm generally a fan of the Pixar/Dreamworks approach to making movies, but in a case like this...why even bother still clinging to any of that if that's not what you really want to do? It feels abundantly clear to me when watching that the storyboarders and animators want to do the really cartoony Dexter's Laboratory type thing, so why not just embrace that?

It feels like the more "traditional" approach to 3D animation is just holding the movie back. To give an example: it feels like some characters have like two different "eye shapes." One is slightly more almond shaped, more naturalistically like an eye. The other is just doing circles and ovals like a cartoon. It feels like they do the oval eyes like 80% of the time, which makes the 20% of the time that they swap back to natural eyes feel so weird and out-of-place???

Anyway, there's some good gags in here. And if you're a fan of the cartooniest cartooniness, there are shots in this film that you could argue have some of the "best" 3D animation ever put up on the big screen.

The actual "plot" does very little for me, but it's serviceable.

This is probably the least I've liked a movie that I've bothered to do a review for on Letterboxd, but it ain't bad!

Btw why doesn't Mavis get to act as cartoony as everyone else...?

item.title: november 14 etc
item.dc:creator: combatdavey
item.description:
So I've been toying with an idea for about a month and it's been sticky enough that I feel like sharing it here.

The short version is that I am thinking of keeping my main blog here at Bear but altering the (week)daily post to be more bloggy and less linksy. The linksy stuff will move to a email newsletter thinger (i.e. DMail 2.0, but with a different name) that I'll probably build out at Ghost or maybe Buttondown. For the sports, trivia, and sports trivia fans out there, I haven't written Oddball for a few weeks for this exact reason, and that would probably also end up at Ghost or Buttondown.

On October 22 I wrote this:

The only thing I really want to do as a job is get paid a normal, non-obscene amount of money to write and/or blog and/or make videos about the handful of things I really like and know a lot about. I suppose this is called being a cOnTeNt CrEaToR, but I'll be damned before I call myself that. The twin pressures of late stage capitalism x algorithmic culture may have reduced all acts of human media creation to "content" in the eyes of billions, but not this guy.

The next day:

Something that's held me back from making digital things (blogs, videos, ebooks, etc) for a living was and is how uncomfortable I am asking people to pay for things I make. This is a holdover from the bad old days where I barely considered myself worthy of kindness, let alone love and support.

The prolific run that I'm on ‚Äî‚Äî a blog post every weekday since August 11 ‚Äî‚Äî has shown me that I have a kind of discipline that I didn't before. It's also helped me enjoy the internet again after a few years where all I could see was the noise and not the signal. Add in that I think the tide is turning against the folks hellbent on destroying or otherwise weaponizing the internet and I think conditions may well be optimal for me to actually make some headway into things I want to make.

More to come, obv, but for now I will leave you with this and my sincere thanks for reading my dumb blog (and maybe, in the future, the other things).

item.title: VHS Memories
item.description:
We had a decent VHS tape collection in my family when I was a kid. Some were store-bought. Some were recorded from TV, like episodes of Star Trek: The Next Generation or Disney Sunday Movies.

Sometimes, when we were in the mood to watch a tape, one of us would stand or sit in front of the VHS shelves and read off titles until there was a consensus among everyone present on something to watch.

Every so often we'd go to a video rental store like Blockbuster or Hollywood Video and bring home a few movies to watch ‚Äì that was always a treat.

For a while, we lived in a house with a neighbor who had the biggest VHS collection I've ever seen. They gladly lent out tapes to their neighbors ‚Äì they even had a sign-out sheet and log to keep track of who had checked out which tapes.

I still have a VCR and a very small VHS collection which includes just a few of the tapes from my family's old collection. I even have a tape rewinder. Occasionally I'll bring home a tape from the thrift store to add to my collection.

The picture and sound quality of VHS tapes can't compare to DVDs, of course. But it's not about the quality, it's about the nostalgia. It's about the intentional experience of watching a movie on physical media. It's about the memories, the feelings of peace, comfort, and safety I had in my youth watching movies at home my family.

As convenient as it is today to watch video on-demand, I miss those days when we were limited to watching what being broadcast over the airwaves and what was in the collections of family and friends and video rental stores ‚Äì and we were happy all the same.

Discuss...

item.title: I'm A Playlist Kind Of Guy
item.description:
So, I‚Äôm in the process of rebuilding my music library so I can finally get away from music subscription services. One of the things that I‚Äôve noticed is that I download albums, but I don‚Äôt really listen to albums. I used to, obviously. Back in the CD days (and before that cassette tapes), you listened to one artist at a time, and usually you did so one album at a time. Unless you made mix tapes, which was fun. Mix tapes were the first playlists.

I‚Äôm much more of a playlist guy these days. I have a Favorites playlist that I‚Äôve been cultivating across streaming services since before there were streaming services. In fact it originated in iTunes back in 2004 when I started at MSU. It has had different iterations since then, but the base is the same.

I have other playlists as well, with more curated experiences and aimed at different genres. It works really well for me.

The issue I‚Äôm going to have now that I‚Äôm moving away from streaming is that I‚Äôm going to have to be my own algorithm. Most of my music discovery will have to be from the music I own, instead of whatever Tidal or Apple Music want me to play next. I think this means I should listen to more albums. I‚Äôll be exposed to more music that way, at least I think so.

I will have to work on a way to discover other music. The song I posted about the other day is one I wouldn‚Äôt have found if not for it being suggested in Tidal as I was listening along. I don‚Äôt know how I‚Äôll be able to replicate that experience yet when I officially move to my self hosted library. I know that LastFM will help a bit, supposedly they give suggestions based on what you‚Äôve listened to in the past. I do not know if ListenBrainz does the same thing or not. I hope so, because I‚Äôm not sure LastFM is long for this world.

For those of you who self host, how do you discover new music?

item.title: Captains Log 1763167004
item.dc:creator: stevedylandev
item.description:
Updates from the bridge:

  • Got my portable cassette tape player this week and absolutely love it ü•≤ Feels great in the hand and I could spend so much time just sitting and listening to music with this thing. My kids love it too, and there's something awesome about watching a 2 year old put on these dinky headphones and watching the tape run. Analog is magic ‚ú®

  • Been contemplating the conundrum I mentioned in Free Speech, Blogs, and P2P Infra, and one thing that has got my gears turning is sync engines. I'm using one in Alcove called Evolu which has the added bonus of being end to end encrypted. With the right setup, you could technically have a BearBlog platform running on multiple sync relays, making it much harder to take down since other people could help run and keep the platform in sync. I also had the idea of building a WYSIWYG note app using Evolu as well. Too much to build, not enough time. Anyway, I really think sync engines could help re-distribute the web in a much more open and free model, and I'm excited about them.

  • Can't keep Linux out of my head. I've been a Mac person since highschool and I still do appreciate the system, but my tinkering on my desktop Linux machine has got me wondering if it's time to switch. Generally I can do most things on Linux that I could do on my MacBook, but the one thing holding me back is hardware. I already have a solid M4 MacBook Pro that would make no sense selling it right now. Framework and System76 have my eye but I'm not sure if they'll have the same performance and battery life of my MacBook. However the allure of complete customization and ownership you get with Linux may eventually get me.

Until next time ü´°

item.title: With Our Heads Held High
item.dc:creator: mirroredworld
item.description:
When I was in High School, the ones I respected (and envied) the most were the ones who seemed like they had their dreams figured out. Instead of an infinitely expanding road, the path laid out before them were clear, even if not always straight.

"I want to be an animator."

"I want to be a doctor."

"I'll make a breakthrough in electrical engineering."

As a jack of all trades who enjoyed a lot of things but had no particular affinity for anything, I can't even begin to fathom condensing my future aspiration other than getting to a point where I could have my own personal library and study, somehow (heh). Even as a child I was not a cute one, my mindset was very practical. Get myself something I could do moderately well, not particularly bothersome, and have a decent pay. It's a mindset that admittedly does serve me well even if it lacks "romance". You see, childhood dreams are full of unreasonable elements. A doomed industry, an oversaturated field, a faraway goal. But regardless, it's a point to reach for, something these people have worked and would work hard for. It has a shiny edge we can't help but admire, I believe. It's the same reason shonen manga is so compelling: to see people struggle, overcoming hurdles come what may, for the sake of this singular goal, no matter how ridiculous. Life happens. The dreams live on.

But in the decade of intervening years, I've come to respect different kinds of people too: people who quietly put old dreams to rest, people chasing after new dreams, people who reignite the dreams they've once buried. It takes tremendous amount of courage to stop. I don't believe it's cowardly at all. To take that in stride, to continue living despite, and to discover what future has to hold has their own shine. Afterall, as long as you're alive, you can always try again.

But how about the rest of us with no dreams to hold onto?

As I grow up, I have gained trust of many people. They confide in me all sorts of things, but there's a common thread. They are ashamed of not having dreams, or not having one lofty enough. They are ashamed of meandering through life. They all think everyone else have everything figured out while they are just there, existing. Here's a secret: it can be high school, it can be college, it can be the years ahead, but a lot of people may not actually find their "calling" until later in life, or even at all. Here's another secret: you can still have a pretty fulfilling life without one.

I used to take living day by day for granted, but when you think about it to continue living on is pretty amazing by itself. I suffer from executive dysfunction and some recurring mental health problems so going through one day to the next, however uneventful, can be a challenge. We get setbacks. We have good days. We have bad days. It's easy to lose sight of tomorrow. To keep showing up, to put one foot after another, takes courage too. It's just easy for us to dismiss that in a world where achievement is all there is.

Even if there is no singular moment to look forward to, there are many small things to celebrate. The pavement after rain. Your favorite series on a rerun. An old friend coming into town. A fantastic hole-in-the-wall. The sky in the morning. A sibling. It's not always easy to keep yourself going, but as long as we're alive I'm sure we'll end up with many things to cherish. Who knows, you might finally end up having "dreams" of your own eventually. Or not, that's fine.

Not having a path to walk on makes me feel lost at times, but it also means I can pursue whatever whenever. My resume is so chaotic it's always the centerpiece of any interview I attend. It may be circuitous, but I don't think everything I've done is a waste of time. Life works in a mysterious way. I always think everything I do builds on top of the ones before it, and the people I encounter intertwine in such a way that I know I will eventually get somewhere. I don't have the vaguest idea where "somewhere" is, but the journey, thorny as it might be, is alright.

For those with dreams, I hope you'll find your way there.

For those who have to make compromises with their dreams, I hope for the best outcome.

For those who haven't found their calling, I pray that one day you can find one.

Even if you don't, just put one foot after another.

Let's continue living, with our heads held high.

item.title: I'd like to build a quiet life amongst the flowers
item.dc:creator: Will Hopkins
item.description:
At this moment, I'm feeling exhausted. I've had a cold or something for last 15 days and am now on some antibiotics to try to clear up any bacterial infection. I've been making a sizable dent in a Costco-sized bottle of generic Mucinex DM.

The last couple weeks have been rough, even if you don't work in government. (And if you do, my heart goes out to you.) Then someone at work brought this to my attention: the Trump admin is floating the idea that they can just revoke passports because they feel like it.[1] Revoking passports and the freedom of movement that comes with them is a standard authoritarian move. If your scapegoat can't escape, it's a lot easier to brutalize them. I may not be trans, but I won't stand by and watch them be attacked any more than the immigrants in my community.

At work, I'm working on a giant data pipeline to move terabytes across the wire. We're standing up new platforms and trying to expand our business. It's stressful.

All of that brings me to this. I want nothing more than a quiet life with people I love. I want to read books, take photos, take walks, play games, laugh, and live a gentle life. That's all any of the immigrants they've kidnapped have wanted. That's all the drag queen dancing for tips wants. On the balance, people just want to live.[2]

Anyway, that's all. I can envision a really gentle and loving life that makes the world around me a little bit better. I can imagine living in harmony with others, and that sounds really nice.

When I wax poetic about this quiet life, a lot of folks have told me, "What's stopping you? Just do it!" The answer, dear reader, is that I give a shit about other people. I can't retire to a quiet life because none of us are free until all of us are free.

  2. Of course there are exceptions but they're so rare they're not worth mentioning, and a rare exception isn't a reason to abuse a group of people. ‚Ü©Ô∏é

item.title: parakeet-mlx
item.dc:creator: Simon Willison
item.description:
parakeet-mlx

Neat MLX project by Senstella bringing NVIDIA's Parakeet ASR (Automatic Speech Recognition, like Whisper) model to to Apple's MLX framework.

It's packaged as a Python CLI tool, so you can run it like this:

uvx parakeet-mlx default_tc.mp3

The first time I ran this it downloaded a 2.5GB model file.

Once that was fetched it took 53 seconds to transcribe a 65MB 1hr 1m 28s podcast episode (this one) and produced this default_tc.srt file with a timestamped transcript of the audio I fed into it. The quality appears to be very high.

item.title: Occasional Weeknote #17
item.description:
We‚Äôve been dealing with a sick bunny around the house this past week. Rabbits have fragile systems and can go from ‚ÄúOK‚Äù to ‚Äúreally bad news‚Äù quickly, so it‚Äôs important (and, at times, exhausting) to stay on top of things when they come up. He‚Äôs doing alright, on antibiotics to deal with a bacterial infection and a few others to help prevent GI stasis, the thing that strikes fear in anyone caring for rabbits.

Unfortunately, I‚Äôm not one of those people that deals with overwhelm and worry by getting extra creative or productive. Instead, I tend to quietly slow down (if not shut down) to deal with what‚Äôs in front of me.

All this to say, that‚Äôs why I feel like I haven‚Äôt really done much this week worthy of sharing. And that‚Äôs OK.

item.title: 3 books with Samuel Arbesman
item.description:
I had a look to see when I first mentioned Samuel Arbesman here. It was 2011: the average size of scientific discoveries is getting smaller.

Anyway I‚Äôve been reading his new book, The Magic of Code (official site).

There‚Äôs computing history, magic, the simulation hypothesis, and a friendly unpacking of everything from procedural generation to Unix.

And through it all, an enthusiastic appeal to look again at computation, as if to say, look, isn‚Äôt it WEIRD! Isn‚Äôt it COOL! Because we‚Äôve forgotten that code and computation deserves our wonder. And although this book isn‚Äôt an apology for technology ("computing is meant to be for the humans", says Arbesman), it is a reminder - demonstrated chapter by chapter - that wonder, delight and curiosity are there to be found.

(And if we look at computation afresh then we‚Äôll have new ideas about what to do with it.)

Now I‚Äôm decently well-read in this kind of stuff.

Yet The Magic of Code is bringing me new-to-me computing lore, which I‚Äôm loving.

So, in the spirit of a virtual book tour - an old idea from the internet where book authors would tour blogs instead of book stores, as previously mentioned - I asked Samuel Arbesman for a reading list: 3 books from the Magic of Code bibliography.

(I‚Äôve collected a couple dozen 3 Books reading lists over the years.)

I‚Äôll ask him to introduce himself first‚Ä¶

Samuel! Tell us about yourself?

I‚Äôm a scientist and writer playing in the world of venture capital as Lux Capital‚Äòs Scientist in Residence, where I help Lux explore the ever-changing landscape of science and technology, and also host a podcast called The Orthogonal Bet where I get to speak with some of the most interesting thinkers and authors I can find. I also write books about science and tech, most recently The Magic of Code, as well as The Half-Life of Facts and Overcomplicated. The themes in my work are often related to radical interdisciplinarity, intellectual humility in the face of complex technologies and our changing knowledge, and how to use tech to allow us to be the best version of ourselves.

The best way to follow me and what I‚Äôm thinking about is my newsletter: Cabinet of Wonders.

I asked for three fave books the bibliography‚Ä¶

#1. Ideas That Created the Future: Classic Papers of Computer Science, edited by Harry R. Lewis

I love the history of computing. It‚Äôs weird and full of strange turns and dead ends, things worth rediscovering and understanding. But it‚Äôs far too easy to forget the historically contingent reasons why we have the technologies that we have (or simply know the paths not taken), and understanding this history-including the history of the ideas that undergird this world-is vital. More broadly, I want everyone in tech to have a ‚Äúhistorical sense‚Äù and this book is a good place to start: it‚Äôs a handbook to seminal ideas and developments in computing, from the ELIZA chatbot and Licklider‚Äôs vision of ‚Äúman-computer symbiosis‚Äù to Dijkstra‚Äôs hatred of the ‚Äúgo to‚Äù command. Because the ideas we are currently grappling with are not necessarily new and they have a deep intellectual pedigree. Want to know the grand mages of computing history and what they thought about? Read this book.

Ideas That Created the Future: Classic Papers of Computer Science: Amazon

#2. In the Beginning‚Ä¶ Was the Command Line, Neal Stephenson

I‚Äôm pretty sure that I first read this entire book‚Äìit‚Äôs short‚Äìin a single sitting at the library after stumbling upon it. It‚Äôs ornery and opinionated about so many computing ideas, from Linux and GUIs to open source and even the Be operating system (it was written in the 1990‚Äôs and is very much of its time). Want to think about these ideas in the context of bizarre metaphors or a comparison to the Epic of Gilgamesh? Stephenson is your guy. This expanded my mind as to what computing is and what it can mean (the image of a demiurge using a command line to generate our universe has long stuck with me).

In the Beginning‚Ä¶ Was the Command Line: Amazon / Wikipedia

#3. Building SimCity: How to Put the World in a Machine, Chaim Gingold

Chaim Gingold worked with Will Wright while at Maxis and has thought a lot about the history of SimCity. And when I mean history, I don‚Äôt just mean the way that Maxis came about and how SimCity was created and published, though there‚Äôs that too; I mean the winding intellectual origins of SimCity: cellular automata, system dynamics, and more. SimCity and its foundation is a window into the smashing-together of so many ideas‚Äìanalog computers, toys, the nature of simulation‚Äìthat is indicative of the proper way to view computing: computers are weirder and far more interdisciplinary than we give them credit for and we all need to know that. Computing is a liberal art and this book takes this idea seriously.

Building SimCity: How to Put the World in a Machine: Amazon

Amazing.

Hey here‚Äôs a deep cut ref for you: in 2010 Arbesman coined the term mesofact, "facts which we tend to view as fixed, but which shift over the course of a lifetime," or too slowly for us to notice. I think we all carry around a bunch of outdated priors and that means we often don‚Äôt see what‚Äôs right in-front of us. I use this term a whole bunch in trying to think about and identity what I‚Äôm not seeing but should be.

Thank you Sam!

item.title: Do The Right Thing Because That's The Only Way
item.dc:creator: nikhil
item.description:
Why do you do the right thing? Because it's the right thing to do. The purpose lies in the deed itself.

I've heard the argument countless times: there's no point in doing the right thing unless the whole world follows the same moral compass. But this is a fundamentally flawed way to think about morality.

First, we need to understand what it means to do the right thing. It changes and evolves according to context. If a friend asks you to take part in a horrible crime, your answer should be no. Helping a friend is usually the right thing to do, but we understand context. No matter how many people pressure you into helping that friend, you won't‚Äîbecause you know the situation. Or you might choose to help, knowing that saving your friend is worth it.

If you require a reason to do the good thing, the right thing, then you are morally bankrupt and looking for justification for your corruption. You do the right thing for its own sake‚Äînot for recognition or to sound clever. How many times have we cheated our company by filing incorrect expenses? Cheated the government by breaking a law? Cheated on partners? These are countless instances where we choose what's beneficial over what's right.

Every time you pick convenience over ethical living, you add decay to your character. Add enough, and soon your core will be rotten. No clever argument can save your soul then. The world can go to hell six ways to Sunday‚Äîdon't think about that. Think about what you are doing. How you choose to live your life will determine how your future generation lives theirs. Why would they believe in your ethics when they never saw you follow them?

I understand there are exceptional cases, but I'm speaking in broader terms. Eighty percent of the time, one must do what is right, not what's convenient. Don't cheat. Don't lie to your friends and family. Be an honourable man. Be proud of yourself. These are clich√©s, yes, but these things make us human. They separate us from acting like animals‚Äîslaves to impulses and what's beneficial in the current moment.

The world is filled with good people too; otherwise, it would have collapsed. Add to the goodness of the world. Do the right thing because that's the only way to live.

item.title: If everyone read everywhere
item.dc:creator: joelchrono
item.description:
As I got to the bus back home a couple days ago, paid my ticket and got in, I couldn‚Äôt help but notice a girl at the second to last seat at the back of the bus. She was reading a book.

It was a long one, I couldn‚Äôt really read the title of it from where I was. All seats occupied, I was standing five or so seats away and the title was written in a cursive font that was not legible from afar.

She was reading the last twenty or so pages, by the art style of the cover, I assume it was some sort of romance YA novel, she seemed to be rather emotional about whatever was going on. I noticed the back and forth of her eyes as she was flying through every line, paragraph, and page.

After a couple minutes a seat freed up right in front of her, I glanced at her general direction, although she was so glued to the book to notice, although I wasn‚Äôt being obvious, I think. I still couldn‚Äôt make up what the title was, so I gave it up, sat down, rested my backpack on my lap, took my Kobo reader out, and continued my sci-fi novel.

I didn‚Äôt notice when she got down from the bus.

Sorry if you expected some sort of romantic twist, or any kind of interaction at all, oh well.

Anyway, that little event really made me think about books read in public.

Today, most people are looking at their phones, tiny screens, each person using different apps, social media platforms, or ad-ridden mobile games, and all of it is for the same thing, feeding from quick entertainment, slop and domapine, in the best case maybe having a chat with someone, although it‚Äôs usually a bubble‚Äîyes, Facebook Messenger here rules ü§¢‚Äîleft on a corner, replying when needed as one continues to consume.

So, I wonder how it would be if we just carried a book around instead?

Wouldn‚Äôt it be a sight to behold? Every person sitting at the bus, with a book on hand, or in ther pockets, reading something and engaging in a whole unique world for themselves. Some guy would be carrying one of those pocket-sized editions of some timeless classic, holding it at their eye level, another wouldn‚Äôt mind the full-sized 900 pages long romance novel, half-way hidden by the open bag its leaning on. Some other person would be standing, one hand firm on handle, the book held with the other in an awkward position, flipping a page with their some weird maneuver, the next guy just tapping on an e-ink device enjoying some sports manga.

Imagine, a never-ending book club, during lunch breaks, after the gym, or on a video-call, conversations sparking when two people notice they are reading the same one, heated discussions when the finale of a long-running series comes out at last. Best-sellers only lasting a few days as the fans catch up on them and the rest just borrow from their friends or libraries, which are fully functional buildings providing easy access to everyone in town, as ids aren‚Äôt needed, just pick what you want and leave it anytime, nobody really worries because there is plenty of supply for the demand.

Who needs ‚ÄúBookTok‚Äù, when your circle of friends will have suggestions and a backlog to share? when everyone is out there displaying their book cover as they read something?‚Äîinstead of watching reels with monotone AI voices at full volume. Approaching people and making friends with shared interests would be much easier too!

I wonder if historians know of a period like this, a time where this was a common thing. I must admit I am completely unaware of a period where this was the case.

Did books ever get widely popular, as to be read in public or be carried around in pockets? I feel most people were too busy trying to get by with whatever working conditions there were at the time, and of course, knowing how to write or read was a privilege that not many people got to have for centuries.

If there‚Äôs something that I know, is that today we are more ‚Äúconnected‚Äù than ever before, and we have more access to information than any previous age, and more books widely available in both physical and digital format, and yet, it seems like books remain a niche, something rarely talked about in public, because you are seen as a snob or a geek when you mention it to someone, somehow.

In any case, just imagine that picture again, that bus, filled with people, wobbling their heads with their books on hand as the driver avoids the potholes on the roadway. The only noise inside? the fluttering of pages turning over, such a pleasant breeze.

Now that I think about it, some people can‚Äôt handle reading while on the move. I guess that‚Äôs how you can tell it‚Äôs just a dream.

It would be nice though.

item.description:
I listened to The Anthropologists over the last few days while doing my laundry at 10 pm and making charts of little poems for children at the anganwadi I‚Äôm working at.

At several points, I thought that I must buy a physical copy of the book because I like the little snapshots it contains of city life. I imagined holding the book in my hands, rereading it in bits and pieces, underlining parts where Asya and Manu, the married protagonists living in an unnamed ‚ÄúCity,‚Äù visit cafes, have dinner with their elderly neighbour or host friends at their own apartment. All the things I‚Äôd like to do someday, too‚Äìa home shared with a person I love, spending our free hours and days getting to know our city and its people.

I described the book to my book club thus: ‚ÄúYou know those Tumblr pics of sunny apartments you wish you could step into or an art-filled, cafe-frequenting life you wish you could live? This is what this book is.‚Äù It‚Äôs like a picture, expanded.

But it‚Äôs not just descriptions, which is what a lot of my writing ends up being when I attempt to capture a similar feeling. There‚Äôs dialogue, movement, emotions in response to dialogue and movement. My writing slows down everything, as if I‚Äôm repeatedly pausing a video to tell people what‚Äôs happening. Here, that‚Äôs not the case. You don‚Äôt just step into a picture‚Äìyou move around the room, you follow its residents out through the door and into the city, taking a walk with them. It‚Äôs a book I wish I were able to write; there‚Äôs a lot to learn here.

Maybe I should get a physical copy, after all.
